title: Exploring an Existing 3D Model
description: Learn how to navigate and understand an existing 3D model in Fusion 360. This tutorial works with any model you already have open.

steps.title: View the Model from Different Angles
steps.instruction: Use the ViewCube in the top-right corner to rotate your view. Click on 'Front', 'Top', and 'Right' to see different orthographic views.
steps.detailedText: Understanding your model from multiple angles is crucial. Orthographic views (Front, Top, Right) show exact proportions without perspective distortion. The isometric view helps you see the overall 3D shape.

qcChecks.text: Can see the model from front view
Can see the model from top view
Can see the model from isometric view

steps.title: Examine the Timeline
steps.instruction: Look at the timeline at the bottom of the screen. Each icon represents a feature in the model's history.
steps.detailedText: The timeline shows how the model was built, step by step. This is called 'parametric history' - you can go back and edit any step, and changes will propagate forward. This is one of Fusion 360's most powerful features.

qcChecks.text: Timeline is visible at the bottom of the screen
Can identify different feature types (sketch, extrude, fillet, etc.)

warnings.text: If timeline is hidden, right-click and select 'Show Timeline'

steps.title: Inspect a Feature
steps.instruction: Double-click on any feature in the timeline to edit it. This reveals the parameters used to create it.
steps.detailedText: By inspecting features, you can understand the designer's intent. Look at dimensions, constraints, and relationships. This helps you learn good modeling practices from existing designs.

qcChecks.text: Can see dimension values and options

warnings.text: Press Escape to cancel without making changes

steps.title: Check the Browser Panel
steps.instruction: Look at the browser panel on the left side. Expand 'Bodies' and 'Sketches' to see all elements.
steps.detailedText: The browser shows the hierarchical structure of your design. Bodies are the solid 3D shapes. Sketches contain the 2D profiles used to create features. Components organize related geometry together.

qcChecks.text: Browser panel is visible on the left

steps.title: Measure the Model
steps.instruction: Press 'I' to open the Inspect tool, then click on faces or edges to measure distances and angles.
steps.detailedText: The Inspect tool is essential for understanding existing designs. You can measure: distances between faces, edge lengths, hole diameters, angles between surfaces, and more. This information is crucial when modifying or replicating designs.

steps.title: Section Analysis
steps.instruction: Go to Inspect > Section Analysis to see a cross-section of the model. This reveals internal features.
steps.detailedText: Section analysis cuts through the model to show internal structure. This is essential for understanding: wall thicknesses, hidden cavities, internal threads, and how parts fit together. Move the section plane to explore different areas.

qcChecks.text: Can see internal structure of the model

warnings.text: Section analysis is temporary - it won't affect your model

steps.title: Model Exploration Complete
steps.instruction: You now know the essential tools for exploring any 3D model in Fusion 360.
steps.detailedText: These exploration skills are fundamental: 1) Viewing from multiple angles, 2) Reading the timeline, 3) Inspecting features, 4) Using the browser, 5) Measuring geometry, 6) Section analysis. Practice these on different models to become proficient.

qcChecks.text: Understand how to navigate the Fusion 360 interface
